entry.title: Surfacing Semantically Similar Content
entry.content:
Refactoring Content

A common problem with technical documentation management is that documentation teams tend to have a lot of stressed-out contributors working on shared content that may be scattered across multiple departments and revised over an extended period of time. This is a recipe for content bloat and redundancy.

All content needs some degree of custodial refactoring. Often refactoring takes the form of deduplication processes or merging similar content into a single source of truth (SSOT). [[extra need for SSOT in LLMs]]

Eventually, I'd like to contain a pool of content in a local LLM for RAG purposes. In taking baby steps toward that goal, I came across txtai and put together a prototype that surfaces semantically same or similar chunks in the form of a report. using a simple Markdown file as input.

The processing is straightforward:

  1. preprocess_markdown.py¬†- Chunks MD by heading to populate a JSON file.

  2. index_chunks.py¬†- txtai (sentence-transformers/all-MiniLM-L6-v2) indexes JSON file.

  3. report_similarity.py¬†- txtai compares paragraph vectors. Reports similarity clusters and vector scores.

GitHub repo here:¬†https://github.com/shealy2020/single-md-txtai-report

I set out to use the hierarchical structure of the Markdown file as a vector dimension contributing to vector scores, but I couldn't figure out how to do that. Instead, I fell back to just comparing paragraph content under headings, so I might as well have compared blocks of text in a *.txt file.

My goal is to leverage what I've learned about comparing vectorized MD chunks and then apply it to¬†DITA, which is a highly-structured authoring XML format with a lot of tagging and other metadata that could be helpful for vector searches.

entry.title: LLM Prompt Organizer
entry.content:
LLM Session Limits

I use the freely available versions of ChatGPT, Claude, and Gemini. These LLMs impose limits on a per session basis, calculated by some combination of request counts and token usage. The table below contains the approximate limitation criteria for non-subscription users.

Service Key Usage Limits Approx. Token / Context Window
ChatGPT Limited GPT-4o usage per ~5-hour window. ~128k tokens (input + output).
Claude Message/session limit, resets ~every 5 hrs. ~200k tokens (input + output).
Gemini ~2 req/min, ~50 req/day (API); ~5 prompts/day (app). Up to ~1M input / 65K output tokens.

LLM Prompt Organizer

Given that I use the free LLM versions, I built tool to increase prompt efficiencies, which provides as much bang as possible from my sessions. Also, this project gave me another chance to use [vibe coding] as an aid in building this prompt tool.

Clone or download LLM Prompt Organizer on Github here.

Why Use This Tool?

The Problem with Unstructured Prompts

  • Important context gets buried in long text blocks.
  • Reusing successful prompt patterns requires copy-pasting and manual editing.
  • No clear separation between instructions, context, constraints, and data.

The Solution: Semi-structured Prompts

The LLM Prompt Organizer helps you create reusable prompts by:

  1. Separating concerns - Breaks your prompt into logical components (role, context, task, format, etc.)
  2. Ensuring completeness - Visual interface reminds you of all the elements that make prompts effective
  3. Enabling reusability - Saves JSON files as templates for similar tasks.
  4. Improving clarity - JSON's semi-structured format helps the LLM understand the request.
  5. Supporting iteration - Users can easily modify specific sections without rewriting everything.

Quick Start

  1. Download the prompt-form-output json-1.html file from Github.
  2. Open it in a web browser.
  3. Deactivate any fields irrelevant to your prompt.
    or
    Import an existing JSON prompt file.
  4. Add custom fields (Optional).
  5. Enter your content in the active fields.
  6. Export your prompt by clicking "Download JSON" or "Copy JSON".
  7. Upload the JSON file directly or paste the content into the chat interface.

JSON Output Sample

Your generated JSON will similar to this:

{
    "instructions": "Process and respond to this prompt.",
    "role": "You are an experienced data analyst specializing in retail performance.",
    "context": "You are analyzing Q4 2024 sales data for a mid-sized retailer operating in North America. The dataset includes metrics such as total revenue, number of transactions, and product category breakdowns.",
    "task": "Identify the top three sales trends and provide insight into what factors may have contributed to these patterns.",
    "format": "Present your findings as three concise bullet points, each with one supporting sentence.",
    "examples": "- Example Trend: Seasonal spike in apparel sales due to holiday promotions.\n- Example Trend: Increased online sales driven by targeted email campaigns.",
    "constraints": "Focus only on quantitative insights supported by data. Avoid speculation not backed by sales metrics.",
    "data": "region,sales,transactions North America,1200000,32000 Europe,900000,28000 Asia,1100000,30000",
    "audience": "Retail operations managers looking for actionable insights to guide Q1 2025 planning."
}

The instructions key/value is automatically included and tells the LLM how to process the JSON content.

entry.title: Prompt Efficiencies
entry.content:
Token Efficiency Cheat Sheet

Conserve tokens = longer sessions + faster responses + fewer cutoffs

1Ô∏è‚É£ Prompt Design

‚úÖ Do

  • Keep prompts concise: use direct verbs (‚Äúsummarize,‚Äù ‚Äúrevise,‚Äù ‚Äúexplain briefly‚Äù).
  • Reference earlier text instead of re-pasting it.
  • State the output size:
    • ‚ÄúIn 3 bullet points.‚Äù
    • ‚ÄúUnder 100 words.‚Äù
    • ‚ÄúCode only‚Äîno explanation.‚Äù

üö´ Don‚Äôt

  • Repeat long setup text (‚ÄúAs I mentioned earlier‚Ä¶‚Äù).
  • Ask multiple tasks in one prompt if they can be done sequentially.
  • Use filler (‚ÄúCould you please kindly explain‚Ä¶‚Äù).

2Ô∏è‚É£ Conversation Management

  • Stay in the same chat thread so context persists.
  • Split long projects:
    1. Outline
    2. Draft one part
    3. Revise iteratively
  • Delete or summarize unneeded sections before continuing.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Handling Large Text

  • Paste only relevant sections (‚ÄúHere‚Äôs the last 30 lines‚Äù).
  • Summarize before submission (‚ÄúThis 20-page doc covers X, Y, Z‚Ä¶‚Äù).
  • Use compressed summaries or keywords when possible.

4Ô∏è‚É£ Service-Specific Tips

Service Efficiency Tactics
ChatGPT GPT-4o‚Äôs tokenizer is efficient. Reuse previous messages and cap outputs.
Claude Takes long input well ‚Äî summarize documents instead of feeding full text.
Gemini Large window; main limit is requests/day. Keep prompts precise and output short.

5Ô∏è‚É£ Output Control

  • Ask for structured formats (Markdown, table, JSON).
  • Set maximums:
    • ‚ÄúExplain in ‚â§5 sentences.‚Äù
    • ‚ÄúShow first 10 lines only.‚Äù
  • For code: ‚ÄúReturn only the function definition.‚Äù

6Ô∏è‚É£ Quick Math

Word Count ‚âà Tokens
75 words ~100 tokens
500 words ~650 tokens
1,000 words ~1,300 tokens

Goal: Short, direct, scoped prompts ‚Üí 3‚Äì5√ó token savings.
